+EyeSnipeYou So what if he sounds like a girl? It's so immature and

seriously, look at you...so pathetic hating on a little kid for no reason. 
You criticize Samuel for his young age and yet...you're the one acting 
immature and childish. I bet Samuel is even more mature than you. He's 
basically sacrificing his childhood and will start working from such a 
young age. He will bear with all the hardships in the kpop industry while 
still being a child (Do you even know how much shit kpop idols have to deal 
with on a daily basis?). The fact that at his age he's already determined 
to deal with this resposibility shows that he's more mature than you.

And please, it's just a music video. A lot of kpop groups release 
embarrassing/cheesy MVs, but then later on they come up good MVs/concepts. 
There's no need to make so much fuss about it. You should be blaming the 
company not Samuel, he doesn't run the company and he most likely didn't 
choose this concept nor his clothes. The company decides all that stuff.

Regardless of how embarrassing this video is, it still showcases these kids 
talent and potential. And that's what really matters. In this video we can 
clearly see that Samuel is a good dancer for his young age. And in his live 
performances, he even tries his best to sing live despite the energetic 
choreography. His live vocals may not be perfect, but then again, he's 
really young and at least he's trying his best to sing live. There are 
quite a few other idols who are way older than him and still lipsynch most 
of the time, so...Samuel's effort should be commended *not* looked down on 
by immature people like you.

"By the time his balls even drop" <-- Girl please...Samuel at only 13 
freaking years old is going to take on the *FREAKING.KPOP.INDUSTRY*. That 
little kid has got *WAAAY more balls* than anyone in this comment section 
(including me). I'm pretty sure *NO ONE* in this comment section would have 
the balls to do what this kid is doing, let alone doing it at friggin 13 
years old. Do you even know how harsh/sketchy/dark/dangerous the Kpop 
industry really is? You probably don't know shit about everything that goes 
on behind the scenes in the kpop industry, so...you better start educating 
yourself so that you can understand why Samuel has got way more balls than 
you.

that could be just a coincidence ^^; (shout out to any 1990 babies? Anyone? 
ANYone??). Anyways 1PUNCH fighting!!

I speak only for myself, but I like how young artists, even if they're not 
born in the musical era that they jam with, are still inspired by whatever 
related styles they choose. I mean, dang, I'm a green-horned 24, but I can 
still greatly appreciate Nat King Cole, Ella Fitzgerald, JAMES BROWN (I 
caught that sample in the beginning ^^) and the late miss Etta James RIP, 
to name a few. I'll never be able to relate intimately with the 70s music 
like my dad or 80s music like my mom, but because they exposed me to the 
joys of both, I'm able to respect related music even to the point of having 
a favorite artist or two. Age shouldn't be a sole qualifier to love music. 
I wish people wouldn't be too hard on these kids. Too much or not, I love 
what they did with this video.﻿

comments.text:
+ChimChimSekushiDesu Ok, sorry for not realizing that you meant 'you' as in 
general, English is not my native language so it might be difficult to make 
my point but I'll try.
 I feel just that it's so unlogical for us to say that "they cant wear this 
because___" and other 'us vs them' mentality. People always assume. 
Assuming is really ignorant.. I mean for all you know, these boys here 
might actually KNOW the history behind this hairstyle and so on. Also it's 
absolutely ridiculous for you to compare this to nazi get-up or 
black-face.. cmon girl...
I just mean that just because somebody did a style first, such as this 
hairstyle, doesn't mean that someone of different culture cannot wear it. 
These boys have no malice intentions. They are not racists or anything 
else.  People need to lighten up. If we would get riled up over every 
single thing, no one would be allowed to do anything. No one would learn 
anything. Everyone would be scared of accidentally offending somebody 
because "ohh maybe this color combination symbolizes something to this 
group of people" when this person simply just likes the colors. This boy 
appreciates this particular hairstyle.
 If one identifies too much with a group, they'll lose their individuality.
I know that there will always be people who get angry over something that 
they find to be their own. It is a whole different thing to wear something 
out of malice, for example a nazi uniform than to wear a simple hairstyle 
that has been around with many cultures. People need to chill out because 
everything has it's own history and deeper meaning. Also, I'm just saying, 
everyone is ignorant in something, even you. There is always someone in 
this world to get angry to someone over a matter of just not knowing. I am 
not saying that it's a good excuse to wear a nazi uniform but for example, 
if there was a group of people whose ancestors came up with the idea of a 
red mini skirt and it is tied with a horrible and significant history with 
these people, would you stop wearing the skirt? (you can replace the skirt 
with any other neutral looking thing that has been around and seen on many 
people for some time now) and cases like these would keep coming up.. you 
are not allowed to wear it just because you are not them!
In my home country, there are SO MANY people who have this hairstyle. It's 
seen as a norm here. Also men tend to have super long hair in general here.
Let's say that my white friend would get this hairstyle and knew about the 
history, then what? It's ok?? 
Btw,  Everyone's hair turns into dreadlocks if you never comb it, so 
probably everyone had dreadlocks before combs were invented. Jamaicans 
definitely weren't the first people with dreadlocks. And by the way, many 
of us black women straighten our hair, Is that wrong too?

Again, my english is not good but I just hope to get you see some 
perspective with THIS issue with this hairstyle - NOT with a nazi uniform. 
sorry for long text ^^
comments.author: NemoRosa700

comments.text:
+NemoRosa700 Excuse me for not realizing you wouldn't see that I meant 
'you' in a general sense. Your opinion on the matter is still ignorant 
though. I agree you can't force someone to not do what they want, but it's 
like saying someone can wear whatever clothing they want because it's their 
money and their clothing. They could be wearing a Nazi get up, Native 
American tribal clothes, black face, baggy pants and a tattooed tear on 
their face, and YES they have the right to wear and do whatever they want 
cause it's their own body. BUT all of those things have a deeper meaning 
than just being cloth or fashion statements. They have a terrible or 
meaningful history to them that no on who doesn't realize the repercussions 
should appropriate. THERE ARE going to be people who will backlash you for 
it. It may not be me and it may not be you, but there WILL be people and 
I'm only helping it along as to why. In a way I'm playing the devils 
advocate. You shouldn't denounce the importance of things to someones 
culture just because you're ignorant. Enlighten yourself and you'd be 
surprised at what you find.
comments.author: ChimChimSekushiDesu

comments.text:
+ChimChimSekushiDesu I did not tell you how you or anyone should feel, 
don't put words in my mouth. If one feels offended then fine. I also 
personally couldn't care less if they have dreadlocks because still, it's 
their own body and hair = nobody owns a hairstyle. It makes you all look 
like twats when anyone goes around saying that.
comments.author: NemoRosa700

comments.text:
+NemoRosa700 Sigh, whether they know or not I honestly don't care, it's not 
under my jurisdiction. I'm just validating why some people have talked out 
about it because, shame me!, for feeling compassion towards those who have 
their culture made insignificant. And actually, dreadlocks have only been 
known prior to Jamaicans in Hindu yogis--diffused thanks to their 
enslavement when brought to the Americas, and Jamaicans were the only ones 
to hold them in such high regard and made them a religious thing. The 
'many' that you speak of is actually a false statement. Whether or not it 
was spread, these boys are obviously wearing it/fashioned in it's urban 
tradition (the Rastafarian way), so that kills your argument of it being 
influenced from another culture. Like I said, I think they look good with 
it, and I don't care, but you shouldn't tell someone what they should and 
should not find offensive without knowing where they're coming from. It 
makes you all look like bigots.
comments.author: ChimChimSekushiDesu

comments.text:
+ChimChimSekushiDesu I think they know.. both grew up in America. And
